description: From Latin exhaustus, past participle of exhaurīre (“to draw out, drink up, empty, exhaust”), from ex (“out”) + haurīre (“to draw (especially water), drain”).

entries.meaning: A system consisting of the parts of an engine through which burned gases or steam are discharged; see also exhaust system.
The steam let out of a cylinder after it has done its work there.
The dirty air let out of a room through a register or pipe provided for the purpose.
An exhaust pipe, especially on a motor vehicle.

verbs.description: exhaust (third-person singular simple present exhausts, present participle exhausting, simple past and past participle exhausted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To draw or let out wholly; to drain off completely (:liquid)
examples: The water was exhausted out of the well.
Moisture of the earth is exhausted by evaporation.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To empty by drawing or letting out the contents
(transitive, literally, figuratively) To use up; to deplete, drain or expend wholly, or until the supply comes to an end
examples: My grandfather seemingly never exhausts his supply of bad jokes.
I exhausted my strength walking up the hill.

entries.meaning: (transitive) to tire out; to wear out; to cause to be without any energy
(transitive) To bring out or develop completely

examples: That subject has already been fully exhausted.

entries.meaning: (transitive, chemistry) To subject to the action of various solvents in order to remove all soluble substances or extractives
examples: to exhaust a drug successively with water, alcohol, and ether
